resources:
Te Hiringa O Te Reo
Te Hiringa o Te Reo is a language 
resource designed specifically for those who are interested in learning basic Māori language but have limited opportunities to attend regular language classes. 

From this basic understanding of te reo Māori participants can then decide to enrol on a part/full time language programme.
Before you begin this reo Māori (Māori language) course please become 
familiar with the content of the Intro section and revisit it often throughout the course. Mihi A greeting and welcome to you from the Ngāti Toa iwi, who are the tangata whenua of the Porirua area, where this course was developed.
Opening Karakia> A prayer for the commencement of this course and lessons. It is recommended that you recite this prayer before you commence each lesson.
Waiata Te Hiringa o Te Reo song for this course.
Closing Karakia> A prayer for the completion of this course and each lesson. When finished for the day, it is recommended that you recite this closing prayer.
Te Wāhanga Tuatahi This is the 'first part' of a four-part course each made up of five lessons (one lesson for each weekday).
Te Wāhanga Tuarua This is the 'second part' of a four-part course each made up of five lessons (one lesson for each weekday).
Te Wāhanga Tuatoru This is the 'third part' of a four-part course each made up of five lessons (one lesson for each weekday).
Te Wāhanga Tuawha This is the 'last part' of a four-part course each made up of five lessons (one lesson for each weekday).
Each lesson provides
Ngā Whāinga Akoranga (Learning Outcomes) 
 • He Whakamārama(Explanation) 
 • Ngā Kupu Hou(New Words) 
• Whakarongo – Kōrero (Listen – Speak) 
• Hei Mahi (Exercises)


This language course makes use of text and audio for learning and interactive exercises to complete each lesson stage.

Further Study http://www.whitireia.ac.nz/AreasOfInterest/Te-Reo-Maori/Pages/TeReoMaori.aspx
NGA WHAINGA AKORANGA You will be able to greet one person,two people and more and you will learn how to reply to a greeting. HE WHAKAMARAMA Greeting and finding out who someone is and where they are from are important in the interaction between people. Who you are and where you come from is usually starting point of conversations amongst many Māori as they begin to establish the kinship relationship between each other.Te Hiringa O Te Reo will begin by examining the patterns and structures that enable dialogue for this interaction. HE WHAKAMARAMA ANŌ HE KÖRERORERO
In te reo, there are 5 vowels. A E I O and U. These can be said as long sounds and short sounds. When written, the long sounding vowel can be written in two ways.
 
 \ \ 1. aa \ \ \ \ ee \ \ \ \ ii \ \ \ \ oo \ \ \ \ uu
 2. ā \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ ē \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ ī \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ ō \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ ū


 Either as two vowels or with a macron (a small line over the top of the vowel that is long)
The idea is to be consistent with which one you choose to use and not to inter-mix the 2.
When addressing people, names that are two syllables or less, use ‘e’ in front of the name.
Usually the word koro is used to address an elderly man; kui is used to address an elderly woman, tama to address a young man or boy and hine to address a young woman or girl.
Mā includes another or others with the person greeted.
About Guidelines

 ki roto i tēnei wānanga Māori.

//Ngā Kupu Hou (New Words) Tangata person/man Tāngata people Wahine woman Wāhine women Whakarongo listen Kōrero speak Mihi greet Koe you Kōrua you two Koutou you, more than 2 Whānau family Rangatira chiefly person Whanaunga relation Tāne man/men Tokomaha many (people) Tukuruatia repeat Tokorua two people
//Day2 Data Explanation In this section you will learn how to ask a person how she/he/they is/are. You will also learn a little on how to use the pronouns, tāua, tātou, māua, mātou, rāua, rātou in a reply. See the table below. Do not be too concerned with learning this off by heart right now, it is only important to get the understanding for the reply to asking someone how they are, 1 person, 2 people, 3 or more – a group. Tātaki/tauītanga

Tautahi tāpiti
(first person, inclusive)

Tautahi tāporo
(first person, exclusive)

Taurua
(second person)

Takitahi
Singular,1 person

Ahau/au
(I/me)

Takirua
Dual,2 people

Tāua(ahau + koe)
 we 2, you + I

Māua(ahau + ia)
we 2, he/she + I

Takitoru
Plural, 
3 or more people

Tātou(ahau + koe + koe…)
we all, including

Mātou(ahau + ia + ia + ia…)
we all, but not you

Kei te pēhea koe? – How are you?
Kei te pai ahau. – I am fine.
Kei te pēhea kōrua? – How are you 2?
Kei te pai māua. – We are fine. (2)
Kei te pēhea koutou? – How are you (more than 3)
Kei te pai mātou. – We are fine. (2+)
Te reo Māori is very specific when talking about people. As in the table above you see that there are different words for “we” inclusive and for “we” exclusive. All of this means is that when you use the words, māua, mātou, tāua and tātou, the listeners know who is being included in the conversation and who is not being included – (excluded).
Kei te pēhea koe e Tama?
How are you Tama? Kei te pai ahau.
I’m fine thanks Kei te pēhea koe e Hoani?
How are you Hoani? Kei te pai ahau
I am fine thanks Kei te pēhea kōrua?
How are the two of you? (you 2) Kei te pai māua
We are fine.	(2 of us, not including Pia who is the speaker) Kei te pēhea koutou tamariki mā?
How are you children?” Kei te pai mātou
We are fine 	 (more than 2 people,excluding the speaker who is Pāpā)” Kei te pai tāua nē Tama
We are fine aren’t we Tama?	(2 people including speaker, Pia)” Kei te pai tāua nē Hoani
We are fine aren’t we Hoani?	(2 people including speaker, Pia” Kei te pai tātou nē e tama mā
We are fine aren’t we boys!	(all three including speaker Pia)” Pia Tama Pia Hoani Pia Hoani and Tama Papa Hoani,Tama and Pia Pia Pia Pia
//Day2 Listen(Whakarongo (Listen)) Tēnā koe e Pita. Hello Pita. Tēnā koe e Tama. Hello Tama! Tēnā kōrua e tama mā! Hello boys! Tēnā koe e Hera! Hello Hera! Tēnā koutou e hoa mā! Hello friends! Tēnā koe Kararaina! Hello Kararaina. Kei te pēhea koe e Tama? How are you Tama? Kei te pai ahau e Pita! I am fine Pita. Kei te pēhea kōrua e tama mā? How are you (2) boys? Kei te pai māua! (2 people) We’re (excluding the person who asked) fine thanks! Kei te pēhea koutou katoa e hoa mā? How are you all (excluding the person who is asking) friends? Kei te pai mātou katoa Kararaina! We (excluding the speaker) are all fine thanks Kararaina! Kei te pēhea koe? How are you? Kei te pēhea kōrua? How are you 2? Kei te pēhea koutou? How are you (more than 2) Kei te pēhea koutou e hoa mā? How are you friends? Kei te pēhea koutou e hine mā? How are you girls? Kei te pēhea koutou e tama mā? How are you boys? Kei te pēhea koutou katoa e hoa mā? How are you all friends?
//HE WHAKAMĀRAMA We can also mihi to those who are leaving and when we leave, too there are phrases that we can say and use. We can say goodbye in a number of ways. Haere rā good bye, said by person who is staying. E noho rā said by person who is leaving. Ka kite i a koe āpōpō! See you tomorrow! Yes, okay, we will see you again! Hei āpōpō e hoa mā! tomorrow friends! Noho ora mai e hoa mā! Stay and be well friends!
//HEI MAHI WHAKARONGO, KŌRERO HOKI Whakarongo – listen Haere rā e Tama. See you Tama (Tama is going) E noho rā e Pita – See you Pita (Pita is staying) Ka kite i a koe āpōpō e Tama! See you tomorrow Tama! Äe e Pita, ka kite anō i a koe! Yes Pita, we will see you again tomorrow! Hei āpōpō e hoa mā Tomorrow friends! Noho ora mai stay and be well!

//Day3 Data Topic(Explanation) In the next two days we will learn how to say who we are, where we are from and where we live. Ko, is used here when saying who someone is or asking who someone is.Nō, is used here for saying where someone is from. See below. 

 Ko Tama ahau.		 --- 		I am Tama. 
Nō Porirua ahau.		 --- 		I am from Porirua 
Ko Hēmi ahau.		 --- 		I am Hēmi. 
Nō Paekākāriki ahau. 		 --- 		 I am from Paekäkäriki. 
Ko Ani ahau.		 --- 		I am Ani. 
Nō Ōtaki ahau. 		 --- 		I am from Ōtaki. 

To say where you live, we use the following- 

Kei Porirua tōku kāinga or Kei Porirua ahau e noho ana. 
My home is in Porirua. or Porirua is where I live. (I live in Porirua) 

Hei tauira:


Ko Tama ahau.		 --- 		I ama Tama. 
Nō Porirua ahau.		 --- 		I am from Porirua. 
Kei Ōtaki ahau e noho ana.		 --- 		I live in Ōtaki. 

Ko Hēmi ahau. 		 --- 		I am Hēmi. 
Nō Paekākāriki ahau.		 --- 		 I am from Paekākāriki. 
Kei Porirua ahau e noho ana		 --- 		I live in Porirua. 

Ko Ani ahau. 		 --- 		I am Ani. 
Ko Nō Ōtaki ahau.		 --- 		I am from Ōtaki. 
Kei Te Whanganui-a-Tara tōku kāinga. --- My home is in Wellington.(I live in Wellington
Tēnā koe e hine! 
Ko Hēmi ahau! 
Nō Paekākāriki ahau. 
Kei Porirua ahau e noho ana. 

Hello young lady. 
I am Hēmi. 
I am from Paekākāriki. 
I live in Porirua.
Kia ora e Hēmi. 
Ko Ani ahau. 
Nō Ōtaki ahau. 
Kei Te Whanganui-a-Tara tōku kāinga. 

Hello Hēmi. 
I am Ani. 
I am from Ōtaki. 
My home is in Wellington. To ask someone where they are from and where they live we can ask in the following way. 

Kia ora e hoa. --- Hello friend. 
Nō hea koe? --- Where are you from? 
Kei hea koe e noho ana? --- Where do you live?


Asking someone where they are from and where they live can sometimes be two different things. As we have seen in the previous examples, Hēmi and Ani are not from where they are currently living. So do keep this in mind when someone asks you these questions or when you in turn ask the same. Sometimes in addition, Kia ora e hoa at the end of a conversation can just be an acknowledgment meaning, Okay or Well then or even Thanks. See below.
Hera: 
Kia ora e hoa! 
Nō hea koe? 
Kei hea koe e noho ana?
Hi there friend! 
Where are you from? 
Where do you live?
Pare: 
Tēnā koe e hoa! 
Nō Porirua ahau. 
Kei Porirua ahau e noho ana.
Hello there friend! 
I am from Porirua. 
I live in Porirua.
Pare: 
Nō hea koe? 
Kei hea koe e noho ana?
Where are you from? 
Where do you live?
Hera: 
Nō Porirua ahau. 
Kei Te Whanganui-ā-Tara ahau e noho ana.
I am from Porirua. 
I live in Wellington.
Hera: 
Kia ora e Pare. 
Noho ora mai.
Well then, 
Stay and be well
Pare:
 Kia ora e Hera.
Thanks.
//Day4 Data Topic(Explanation)
In this session we will be looking at how to say who you are and where you are from without asking questions and without giving your name. Māori have a means of identification that is known as reciting your pepehā or using names of prominent landmarks to say where you are from and who your ancestors are. 

This is a good way to say who you are without actually using your name.
Here again we use ko to start our sentences as the words that follow ko are names of places, rivers, mountains as well as people: 

Ko Whitireia te maunga 
Ko Parumoana te moana 
Ko Takapūwāhia te marae 
Ko Ngāti Toa te iwi 
Ko Te Rauparahā te tangata


Whitireia is the mountain 
Parumoana is the ocean 
Takapūwāhia is the marae 
Ngāti Toa is the iwi / are the people 
Te Rauparahā is the ancestor.


There are other ways this can be said, for example including the canoe, and adding a greeting at the beginning or end with saying just Tēnā koutou katoa!

Take out your notebook and pen and listen and write few more words:
Ngā Kupu Hou HE WHAKAMARAMA
Whakamāorītia / whakapākehātia rānei ēnei kōrero
Translate into Māori/English
//Day5 Data (Explanation)
Today we shall look at something completely different to what we have been doing in the previous four days. The work will be based on the names of days of a week and the months of the year. We shall also learn how to ask and say what the day is, what the month is and what the year is.


Ko te aha tēnei rā – What is the day? or What day is this? 
Ko te aha tēnei mārama – What is this month? or What month is this? 

Ko te aha is answered with Ko te
There has been a move to shift the emphasis from Anglicised Māori to authentic Māori words.


The Anglicised Māori words are words derived from English or sounds like English. 
Tūturu – Current Māori words that are used today
//Week2day1 Data In this session, we will be finding out how to ask names, especially the members of a whānau and their respective positions within the whänau. Within the context of the whānau, we will also look at first person pronouns as well as definite and indefinite particle(s). The first question is Ko wai or who.
 Answering the ‘ko wai’ question always begins with ‘Ko’ then the name.


E.g.
Ko wai? 
Ko (the name)


For now though we are just concentrating on asking: 
Who are you? 
Who am I? 
Who is (s)he?


Below are the first person pronouns 
Au or ahau (I/ me) 
Koe (you - one person) 
la (he/ she, him/her).

N.B: la can apply to either a male or a female.
In English an ‘s’ is added to the noun to show two or more (plural). In Māori ngā goes before the noun to show two or more.


E.g.
Te tama = The son 
Ngā tama = The sons


He is slightly different in that it could mean a person/thing or some people/things. There is an indefinite number.

He tama = A son 
He tama = Some sons
HE KŌRERORERO HEI MAHI WHAKARONGO, KŌRERO HOKI
Asking someone’s name can be said in two ways:


Ko waikoe or Ko wai tō ingoa? 
Who areyou or Who is your name?


Ko wai - Who am 
au? - I?


Ko Whare - You are 
koe - Whare


Ko wai - koe? 
Who are - you?


Ko Marama - au 
I am - Mārama


Ko wai - ia? 
Who is - she/he?


Ko Mere - ia 
She is - Mere
Me āta whakarongo koe ki te kaikōrero, ā, kātahi ka tukuruatia te kōrero.Listen to the speaker and then repeat. A muri ake nei he wā poto mōu hei whakaharatau te kōrero.Afterwards, there will be a short pause to allow you to practice the question and the answer. 
The dialogue below is between Whare and Mārama so you can assume the role of either person.

Kei whea koe? Kei whea ia? Kei whea ahau? Kei whea tō hoa? Kei whea ona mātua tïpuna? Kei whea toku kaiako? Kei whea te whaea o Roimata? Kei whea a Hēmi? Kei whea ngā tama a Kata? Kei whea ō mātua? Kei whea te whaea o Mere rāua ko Kata? Kei whea te matua o Kata? Kei whea te whaea o ngā tama? Kei whea te matua o Kata räua ko Hōri? Kei whea te mātāmua a Whare rāua ko Mārama? Kei whea te pōtiki a Whare rāua ko Mārama? Kei whea ngā tamariki a Whare rāua ko Mārama?
Where are you? Where is she/he? Where am I? Where is your friend? Where are his/her grandparents? Where is my teacher? Where is Roimata’s mother? Where is Hēmi? Where are Kata’s sons? Where are your parents? Where are the sons of Whare and Mārama? Where are Mere, Kata and Roimata? Where is the husband of Mārama? Where is the wife of Whare? Kei konā te whaea o Roimata Kei konei te matua o te whānau Kei konā te whaea o Mere rāua ko Kata Kei korā te matua o Kata Kei konei te whaea o ngā tama. Kei korā te matua o Kata rāua ko Hōri Where is the first born child of Whare and Mārama? Where is the last born child of Whare and Mārama? Where are the children of Whare and Mārama?

Anei ētahi kupu hou me nga whakamārama. Here are some new words and their meanings.

You may have noticed that some vowels have a tohutō (macron or a dash) above them. This tells the reader that the length of the vowel sound is twice that of a vowel without the tohutō. Imagine that the vowel is written twice. That approximate sound should be heard.


Ā = AA 
Ē = EE 
Ī = II 
Ō = OO 
Ū = UU


The letter 'T' is pronounced like a soft 'D'. The tip of your tongue is placed just behind your front top teeth on the roof of your mouth.

Ngā Kupu Hou HE WHAKAMARAMA
In this session we will still be finding out who the members of your whänau are and their respective positions within the whānau. Within this context we will be using the a and o categories to show the relationships between whānau members. The question now is, who is the matua/tama/tāina etc of any other given member of the whānau. Seniority will determine the use of an a or an o. 

Ngā mātua tīpuna 		 = 			 Grandparents 

Ngā mātua 							 = 			 Parents 

Ngā tamariki 						 = 			 Children 

Ngā mokopuna 				 = 			 The first born to the last born 

Tuakana/tāina 					 = 			 The older sibling to younger sibling 

N.B: If you are stating a person in a senior position first, then you would use the o, however, if you are stating a person of lesser status first, then you would use the a. 

When showing a relationship between two or more people of equal status within the whänau then those who are married usually use a and those who are not use o.

Ko Whati raua ko Hori nga tungane o nga tamahine. 
Ko Mere ratou ko Kata, ko Roimata nga tuahine o nga tama.

//Week2Day3 Data By the end of this session, you should be able to ask where people are from. We will use pepeha (Iwi proverbs) as a starting point of identification for you to use later. We will then find out how to ask where people are living now.
Anei te pepeha o Ngāti Toa. Pepeha are proverbs that describe Iwi origins. If one were to recite this pepeha it would be safe to say that their tribal origins are from the greater Porirua area or the area where Te Rauparahā once ruled supreme. See if you can find the pepeha that is from your Iwi.


Ko Tainui te waka 
Ko Whitireia te maunga 
Ko Parirua te moana 
Ko Takapūwāhia te marae 
Ko Ngāti Toa te iwi 
Ko Te Rauparahā te tangata


A much simpler way is to say nō Porirua au (I am from Porirua).


N.B: Some iwi say whea while others say hea. This is only a dialectal difference. Whichever one you choose, be rest assured that you will be understood. Nō whea is quite specific in that it is asking where you trace your family origin. Many urban Māori currently may never have been to their whānau marae or urupā (family cemetery) but regardless they will still maintain their iwi is that of their parents. 

Obviously, the place where people live may vary to where the person is from so this needs to be made clear. This will allow us to continue our conversation.


The literal meaning of Kei whea tō kāinga? is Where is your home? 
The intended meaning is closer to 
Where do you live? 
Where are you staying? or 
Where have you made your home?


Although the structure might seem a little strange, try to think in terms of the entire question and answer rather than word for word.

Once you are able to ask where someone lives you will probably realise that the same structure can be used to ask where something is. However, when we are talking about a person or people we must always place an a before their name. If it is an object then Te, Ngā or He, must precede it. If the object has been named after a person then it is regarded as such. 
Kei whea a Hēmi? 
Kei whea te whānau ? 
Kei whea ngā tama?


Kei Taupō a Hēmi. 
Kei Tawa te whānau. 
Kei Taupō ngā tama.
Nō (w)hea? = From where? or where from? 
Answering the nō whea question is like answering all the other pätai (questions) in that they begin with the same word, in this case Nō. 

Nō whea? = From where? 
Nō Porirua = From Porirua
Kei (w)hea tō kāinga ināianei?

Where is your home now?

Answering the Kei whea question is like all the other pätai (questions) in that they begin with the same word, in this case Kei.


Kei whea = At where? 
Kei Porirua = At Porirua

Kei Porirua tōku kāinga ināianei.


At Porirua myAt Porirua my home is now or 
I’m living in Porirua now

He aha tēnā? = What is that? (By the listener)

He aha tērā? = What is that (over yonder)?

//Level 4// // Day1//
During this session you will learn to ask what the particular thing or object is using ‘ko te aha’ with the definitive tēnei (this near speaker), tēnā (that near listener), and tērā (that over yonder).
This question is very similar to ‘He aha?’ however, ‘Ko te aha?’ asks in very specific terms, not general terms. He pukapuka simply says it is a book or some books. Ko te pukapuka tells us that it is the book and we are only talking about the one book.
 To help clarify this concept a bit more, if I held up a pen and asked, “He aha tēnei?” (What’s this?)You could answer it’s a thing, it’s a writing thing, it’s a blue thing, or it’s a long skinny thing that we use to write with – even though you know that it is called a pen. But, if I asked you ko te aha? When I hold up the pen and you know it is called a pen then you can only reply ko te pene - The thing/object is the pen. The use of ‘Ko’ tells us that a name will follow and in this case the name is that of the object – i.e. the pen Yes, we know it is a thing, a blue thing, a writing thing, a long skinny thing that we use for writing, but we want to know exactly what it is. The thing is called a pen. We are speaking in very specific terms. Ko te aha? The what? Ko te pene The pen.

//Day2//
By the end of this session you should be able to ask what the particular things or objects are called and use the plural definitive ēnei (these near the speaker), ēnā (those near the listener), and ērā (those over yonder).
Once again, this question is very similar to ‘He aha?’ However, ‘Ko ngā aha?’ asks specifically about two or more objects or things. He pukapuka simply says it’s a book or some books. Ko ngā pukapuka specifies that we are talking about two or more books and exactly what they are called.
The major difference in this session is the plural forms ngā, ēnei, ēnā, and ērā.
For the plural definitive drop the ‘T’. The rules and sentence structure remain the same as in the previous explanation.
Ēnei = these (by the speaker), Ēnā = those (by the listener), Ērā = those (over yonder).

NGĀ KUPU HOU
//Day 3//
During this session, you will learn to say to whom something belongs to, using either of the ‘A’ and/or ‘O’ possessive categories.
In Māori you are literally saying it is the thing of someone although we usually say, “It is Tama’s”. ‘A’ and/or ‘O’ are the Māori equivalents to of. However, the obvious difference is that Māori have two words that are used for this purpose and the reason is because to Māori, all things are separated into these two basic categories;

The ‘A’ category consists of small objects that can be carried or items that can be controlled by you. The ‘O’ category consists of clothes, parts/sections of something, parts of the body or things that you have no control over.

These categories might seem confusing at first so if you forget the correct category use either until such time that they have become second nature.

So now, when we answer the question,‘Ko te aha?’ we can extend the answer to say what it is and to whom it belongs.

Ko te aha? What is it?
 Ko te pene a Tama. It is the pen of Tama or more commonly said it is Tama’s pen.
 By now you may have noticed that we are being more precise about exactly what the object or thing is, exactly which one by location, and identifying its owner.

By the end of this session you should be able to say to whom something belongs to using either of the ‘A’ and/or ‘O’ possessive categories.
By the end of this session you should be able to say to whom things belong using either of the ‘A’ and/or ‘O’ possessives. As with the singular, the rules for categorizing the plural are exactly the same. Be aware that there are other criteria for categorizing things but these below will suffice for now. NGĀ KUPU HOU
// Day5//
By the end of this session you should be able to use everything we have covered so far this week and where possible include things we have covered from previous weeks.
Ko te aha? asks in very specific terms, not general terms.
 Ko te pukapuka tells us that the thing is called a book and we are only talking about the one book.
 Ko te aha? The what? Ko te pene The pen.

Ko ngā aha? asks specifically about two or more objects or things.
 Ko ngā pukapukaspecifies that we are talking about two or more books and exactly what they are called.
 The major difference from this session was the plural forms ngā, ēnei, ēnā, and ērā.

‘A’ and/or ‘O’ are the English equivalents to of. All things are separated into these two basic categories;
 The ‘A’ category consists of small objects that can be carried or items that can be controlled by you.
 The ‘O’ category consists of clothes, parts/sections of something, parts of the body or things that you have no control over.
 Ko te aha? The what?
 Ko te pene a Tama. It is the pen of Tama or more commonly said It is Tama’s pen.
 As with the singular, the rules for categorizing the plural are exactly the same.
So now when we answer the question Ko ngā aha? We can extend the answer to say what they are, and also to whom they belong.
 Ko ngā aha?					The what?
 Ko ngā aha ēnei? 	 What are these?
 Ko ngā aha ēnā? 	 What are those?
 Ko ngā aha ērā? 	 What are those? (Over yonder)

 Tō hoa: ……………….

 Ko koe: Kei te pēhea tō whānau?
 Tō hoa: …………………
 Ko koe: He aha tō mahi i tēnei ra?
 Tō hoa: ………………
